bibl.title: Letter from Henry Hanson to Henry Rose Carter, February 20, 1922

div1.p: Hanson believes that the yellow fever epidemic along the Peruvian coast has been contained.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Hanson to Henry Rose Carter, February 20, 1922
div1.opener:
DIRECTOR GENERAL
HENRY HANSON
M. D.
I. H. B.
Hanson
BAJO LOS AUSPICIOS DEL
GOBIERNO PERUANO Y LA
JUNTA INTERNACIONAL DE
SANIDAD DE ROCKEFELLER
FOUNDATION
Campaña Sanitaria contra la Fiebre Amarilla en el Perú
OFICINA CENTRAL
AVENIDA PIEROLA 545 - TELEFONO 3428
LIMA -- PERU
February 20, 1922.
NUMERO
____
My dear Doctor Carter:
div1.p:
I have just received your letter of
January 19, in which you ask about the money which you have
deposited in the Banco Mercantil Americano. I have kept this
matter in mind and have conferred with the new manager of the
bank a Mr. Oermacen (I think that is the way it is spelled)
and it was his judgement that it would probably be better to
wait a while. There is still some probability that the Gov-
erment may get a loan from the U.S. and in that case there
certainly will be a rise in the value of the Peruvian currency.
I am in pretty constant touch with the exchange on account of
having my campaign funds in dollars with the Equitable Trust
Company of New York. There has been a slight improvement lately
but not enough to let you come out even on what you deposited
comparing its value in dollars now and then, even including the
interest. The last quotation was 3.57 but it has been up to
3.65, and I rather think that it will go up above that figure
again. You can not convert and come out even unless you get
at least 3.70. Converting at 3.70 you would have $5.00 more
than if you had taken it in U.S.C., when you left last year.

I judge that you have probably received several letters
from me since you wrote this one of the 19th ultmo. I wrote
you quite at length in one of them. In so far as the epidemic
is concerned I think it is gone for good, but I am beginning
my explorations now, with the idea of catching any new focus
and knowing just what the conditions are beforehand. So far
Dr. Caballero has reported nothing from the south and the men
on the job in the north have seen nothing of a suspicious
nature in the old territory.

Personally I should be very glad to see either you
or Dr. White and it would be a great relief of responsibility
to have you here to help me pass judgement and pronounce the
last rites over the defunct Yellow Jack on this coast, but I,
in looking at it from the economical standpoint, can not see
that it is an absolutely necessary expenditure.

As things are now I am pretty much confined to my
Lima Office, and will not be able to leave for the north until
Caballero gets back to take temporary charge here during my
absence. We have developed a rather big and probably a bit com-
plicated organization, but it works and seems to be getting
results. We have quite a system of complete daily weekly and
monthly reports, complete records of house visits, percentage of
breeding etc, and in this way I always know what is going on
in the different sectors. I have been with the men in the field
sufficiently to be able to judge from the reports what the work
is. In this way we compile the records for the final report and
can check on the work at the same time. I inclose copy of the
preliminary report which I sent Dr. Rose, which is only a brief
statement for their immediate use.
